column2: A Person Who Walks; and Eats, or Drinks; Must Sing.
Imagine a provision that says something like –

column3:
A person who –
    (a) walks; and
    (b) (i)   eats, or
           (ii) drinks,
    must sing.

column2: How do we say this in L4?
We haven't done too much violence to the original: we've moved the "and" and "or" around, added indentation, and uppercased some keywords.

Let's do more! As documents grow in complexity, it is natural to introduce defined terms:
    A Qualifying Person is a person who walks and (eats or drinks).
    Every Qualifying Person must sing.
We've added "folding": in the left margin you'll see a clickable button that hides and shows the definition of "Qualifies", for easier reading.

Read one way, we get "Every Person who Qualifies must sing." This is the regulative essence of the rule.

Read another way, we get "A Qualifying Person is one who walks and (eats or drinks)." This is the constitutive essence of the rule.

This takes a bit of getting used to, but we trust there are no substantive objections so far.
